content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The image displays several fragments of fibrofatty tissue. Dispersed within this tissue are multiple, well-circumscribed, basophilic (dark purple) nodules of varying sizes. I can identify at least three to four distinct structures that are morphologically consistent with lymph nodes. The primary task for a pathologist examining this slide would be to systematically evaluate each of these lymph nodes for the presence of metastatic tumor.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I would zoom into this area because it represents one of the candidate lymph nodes identified at low power. It is a standard practice to examine every lymph node at higher magnification to search for metastatic deposits. This particular nodule on the left is well-defined and cellular, making it a primary target for evaluation. The goal is to determine if the cellularity is due to a benign reactive process or infiltration by malignant cells from the primary colorectal cancer. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I zoomed into this specific area because it shows a small, focal, basophilic (dark blue) aggregate of cells that stands out against the surrounding pale pink and white fibroadipose tissue. This structure is separate from the larger, obvious lymph nodes. Such an appearance is highly suspicious and requires high-magnification examination to rule out lymphovascular invasion (LVI), perineural invasion (PNI), or a small tumor deposit, all of which are critical for accurate staging and prognosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to identify all lymph nodes and assess them for metastatic cancer, which is a critical component of cancer staging (N stage). The area highlighted by the green box contains one of these well-defined, basophilic nodules. I am zooming into this specific area to examine this potential lymph node at high magnification to determine if it contains any malignant cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine every piece of tissue, paying special attention to the lymph nodes. The green box is placed on the periphery of the largest and most prominent lymph node in the specimen (the first one from the left). I am zooming into this area to begin my detailed assessment of this node, specifically looking at the capsule and the subcapsular sinus, which are common initial sites for metastatic cancer cells to lodge. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to find and evaluate every single lymph node for metastasis to determine the N stage of the cancer. The area highlighted by the green box contains a small but distinct basophilic aggregate that is suspicious for a small lymph node. It is crucial to examine all such structures, regardless of their size, to ensure an accurate diagnosis and staging. I would zoom into this area to confirm if it is indeed a lymph node and to look for any signs of metastatic tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is positioned over the largest and most prominent lymph node on the left side of the slide. In the context of staging for colorectal cancer, it is mandatory to examine every lymph node for the presence of metastasis. I am zooming into this area to begin the systematic evaluation of the lymph nodes. This high-magnification view is necessary to assess the cellular architecture and identify any potential nests of atypical epithelial cells (cancer cells) within the lymphoid tissue or its sinuses. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

At high magnification, I see a dense and polymorphous population of lymphoid cells, predominantly small, mature lymphocytes with dark, round nuclei. The overall architecture of the lymph node appears preserved, with recognizable lymphoid follicles and intervening sinuses. There are no definitive features of metastatic adenocarcinoma, such as atypical glands, nests of malignant epithelial cells with large pleomorphic nuclei, or tumor-associated desmoplasia. The appearance is consistent with a reactive lymph node, which is negative for metastasis. I would proceed to examine the rest of this lymph node and all other lymph nodes on the slide to confirm this assessment.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see two distinct, rounded vascular-like channels within the connective tissue. Both channels are filled with tightly packed clusters (emboli) of atypical epithelial cells. These cells have large, hyperchromatic (darkly stained) nuclei, irregular nuclear membranes, and scant cytoplasm, which are features of malignant cells (adenocarcinoma). My impression is that this is a clear and definitive example of extensive lymphovascular invasion (LVI). The presence of LVI is a significant adverse prognostic factor.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms that this is a lymph node. It is encapsulated and surrounded by adipose tissue. The node is composed of a dense population of small, dark-staining lymphocytes with scant cytoplasm. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular formations, or nests of tumor cells that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The overall appearance is that of a benign, reactive lymph node. My impression is that this lymph node is negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a dense aggregate of small, round, blue cells, which are lymphocytes, located at the edge of the lymph node and infiltrating into the adjacent adipose tissue. Below this lymphoid aggregate, there is a distinct structure composed of cells with wavy, spindle-shaped nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, which is characteristic of a nerve bundle. There are also a few small blood vessels. I do not see any definite malignant glandular structures or atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is a nerve bundle in close proximity to reactive lymphoid tissue at the periphery of a lymph node. The presence of a nerve is an important finding, and I would continue to scan along its path to rule out any perineural invasion by tumor elsewhere.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense, well-circumscribed aggregate of lymphocytes, confirming this is a small lymph node. The lymphocytes appear mature with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm. There are no atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells to suggest metastasis. The surrounding tissue consists of fibrous connective tissue and adipose tissue, with a few small blood vessels nearby. My impression is that this is a benign (negative) lymph node, showing no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 6. What do you observe when you zoom in?

This high-power view shows the edge of a lymph node. The lower part of the image consists of a dense sheet of small, dark, round cells, which are lymphocytes, consistent with the cortex of a lymph node. This lymphoid tissue is separated from the surrounding adipose tissue (top of the image) by a thin fibrous capsule. In this specific field, the lymphoid population appears uniform, and I do not see any evidence of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glandular structures or clusters of malignant epithelial cells. My impression of this area is a benign/reactive lymph node, but I would need to pan across the entire node to definitively rule out any micrometastasis.
